question:

Hursthouse, (i) _________ virtue ethicists in general, argues that ethics is properly neither situational nor utilitarian and that one ought to seek out virtue and emulate it rather than base oneâ€™s judgments on subjective
concerns or a (ii) _________ weighing of pain and pleasure likely to result from a given action; critics, of course, tend to (iii) _________ that Hursthouse and other virtue ethicists who seek to define virtue merely seek to enshrine their own prejudices under the guise of theory.
Blank (i)
Blank (ii)
Blank (iii)
(A) enigmatic to
(D) pragmatic
(G) posit
(B) breaking away from
(E) quixotic
(H) deny
(C) emblematic of
(F) grandiloquent
(I) cajole
